hints.content:
Let's interpret the frequency table.

Height | Number of Children
- | - 
$37\dfrac14\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid}=3$ children
$38\dfrac12\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid\mid}= 4$ children
$38\dfrac34\text{ in}$| ${\mid\mid}=2$ children
$39\text{ in}$| $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid=6$ children
Each tick mark on the number line represents an interval of ${\dfrac{1}{4}\text { in}}$.

There were $3$ children that measured a height of $\blueD{37\dfrac14\text { in}}$.  

So, we place $3$ dots over $\blueD{37\dfrac14}$ on the number line.   

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (inches) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 37, 38, and 39. Three unlabeled tick marks appear in the middle of each labeled tick mark. . Dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above the first unlabeled tick mark after 37. !

hints.content: Now, let's graph the other measurements on the frequency table.

The correctly graphed measurements are:

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A line plot labeled heights (inches) shows, moving left to right, labeled tick marks at 37, 38, and 39. Three unlabeled tick marks appear in the middle of each labeled tick mark. Dots are plotted as follows: 3 dots above the first unlabeled tick mark after 37, 4 dots above the second unlabeled tick mark after 38, 2 dots above the third unlabeled tick mark after 38, and 6 dots above 39. !

question.content:
Vlad’s family measured the height of all the children to the nearest $\dfrac{1}{4} \text{ in}$. 

Height | Number of Children
- | - 
$37\dfrac14\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid}$
$38\dfrac12\text{ in}$ | ${\mid\mid\mid\mid}$
$38\dfrac34\text{ in}$| ${\mid\mid}$
$39\text{ in}$| $\bcancel{\mid\mid\mid\mid}\mid$

**Graph the measurements from the frequency table on the following line plot.**     
*Click above the line plot to make dots for each of the measurements.*

[[☃ plotter 1]]
